U.S.","body":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ePresident Joe Biden\u0026rsquo;s $2.3 trillion infrastructure proposal is packed with an ambitious green agenda for the U.S.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIncluded in the plan is $620 billion in transportation spending with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/31/fact-sheet-the-american-jobs-plan/\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e$174 billion\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e invested in the electric vehicle (EV) market. The plan will enable automakers to spur domestic supply chains from raw materials to parts, retool factories and give consumers point-of-sale rebates and tax incentives to buy affordable American-made EVs.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eMoreover, it will establish grant and incentive programs for state and local governments and the private sector to build a national network of 500,000 EV chargers by 2030.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eTraditional automakers including Ford (NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/F#NYSE\"\u003eF\u003c/a\u003e), General Motors (NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/GM#NYSE\"\u003eGM\u003c/a\u003e) and Nikola (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/NKL#NASDAQ\"\u003eNKL\u003c/a\u003e, \"\u003eA)) \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eare competing with tech companies such as Amazon (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AMZN#NASDAQ\"\u003eAMZN\u003c/a\u003e), Google\u0026rsquo;s parent Alphabet (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/GOOGL#NASDAQ\"\u003eGOOGL\u003c/a\u003e), Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/INTC#NASDAQ\"\u003eINTC\u003c/a\u003e) and Nvidia Corporation (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/NVDA#NASDAQ\"\u003eNVDA\u003c/a\u003e) to get a piece of the EV pie.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eRecently, reports about Apple (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AAPL#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e) joining the EV bandwagon have surfaced. According to The Korea Times, Apple is close to signing an agreement\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e with LG Magna e-Powertrain (KRX: 066570). \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIf the agreement with LG Magna is reached, the two parties will then jointly establish the precise details for the production of the Apple car, and a prototype might be teased in early 2024.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOne company that stands to benefit from this spectacularly is \u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWorksport (OTC:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/WKSP#OTC\"\u003eWKSP\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDisruptive Innovation\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e\u003ciframe src=\"//player.vimeo.com/video/490551300?title=0\u0026amp;amp;byline=0\" width=\"425\" height=\"350\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eFounded in 2011, Worksport is a globally recognized designer and producer of tonneau or truck bed covers. The Canadian-based company is a disruptive innovator with its mobile solar technology \u0026mdash;\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e t\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ehe TerraVis\u0026trade;.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe technology provides solar power to over 50 million light trucks on the roads today and is a key source of clean energy to recharge upcoming EV trucks. The TerraVis\u0026trade; can provide up to 30% or more of the power needed for the average daily commute.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe TerraVis\u0026trade; system is a first-of-its-kind mobile solar power generation system. It can generate up to 1kWh of mobile power off-grid. The TerraVis\u0026trade; Cor battery system takes power from the cover and stores it in modular battery packs \u0026mdash; storing 1.5 kWh of energy in up to 4 batteries that can be transported in the truck bed using the mounting system.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe TerraVis Cor can also act as a standalone consumer product \u0026mdash; making it available for purchase even if you\u0026rsquo;re not a truck owner. The system will allow the same level of freedom from a power grid, being chargeable via any wall outlet, solar panel or 12V power source.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eEarly Mover Advantage\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWorksport will leverage the TerraVis\u0026trade; system and its position as a Tier 1 original equipment manufacturer (OEM) to secure future partnerships and distribution of its conventional truck bed tonneau covers.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe company has already forged OEM supply partnerships with 2 EV truck nameplates \u0026mdash; one of which is in partnership w\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eith Nissan (OTC:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/NSANY#OTC\"\u003eNSANY\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eApart from the tonneau cover market, Worksport finds itself in the pickup specialty equipment market \u0026mdash; $12 billion as a whole \u0026mdash; with the EV market (\u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.alliedmarketresearch.com/electric-vehicle-market#:~:text=Request%20Now%20!,registering%20a%20CAGR%20of%2022.6%25.\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e$162 billion\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e) and the battery storage system market (\u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.marketsandmarkets.com/Market-Reports/battery-energy-storage-system-market-112809494.html?gclid=Cj0KCQjwh_eFBhDZARIsALHjIKfinmWGLN_A2x6v5-xVkPiQOm2Zwb_roAEWKY3AfU7fdadP44Q0DjIaAj51EALw_wcB\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e$2.9 billion\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e).\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWorksport is now in an enviable position as it stands to support a plethora of EV giants and traditional automotive makers that are committing to electrification.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eRecent Developments\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cul\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"font-weight: 400;\" aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOn June 1, 2021, Worksport forged a working relationship with Ontario Tech University (OTU) that will start as a 2-year contract. With this partnership, the company will get access to the world-class ACE Testing facility, collaborating with the research team that is supervised by Professor Sheldon Williamson, Ph.D.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"font-weight: 400;\" aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWorksport plans to finish prototy\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eping the TerraVis solar truck bed cover system by\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e the end of Q3 2021. OTU and Worksport will complete validation and fine-tuning for TerraVis pre-launch in Q4 2021, and accelerate toward full manufacturing in 2022.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"font-weight: 400;\" aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eTerraVis Cor\u0026trade; has entered the production prototype phase with the first pre-production prototype expected to be ready by early Q3 2021. The prototype system(s) will be fully operational and is expected to mirror the commercial model available at the turn of 2022.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"font-weight: 400;\" aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOn May 27, 2021, Worksport decided to take advantage of its recent opportunities in raising capital to onboard several new hires: 2 full-time industrial engineers, 1 industrial designer with specialties in 3D modeling and interactive preparation, and 2 advisory engineers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"font-weight: 400;\" aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWorksport currently has $10 million in cash and cash equivalents with no long-term debt.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eTo learn more about Worksport, you can visit its website \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://worksport.com/us/\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ehere\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWorksport is a partner of Benzinga. The information in this article does not represent the investment advice of Benzinga or its writers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e ","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/markets/penny-stocks/21/06/21469776/why-you-need-to-watch-out-for-this-new-ev-player-in-2021","image":[{"size":"large","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/2048x1536xUP/images/story/2012/bb98c79a-b08c-4ab6-9f8c-afef0f3090a0.jpg"},{"size":"thumb","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/250x187xUP/images/story/2012/bb98c79a-b08c-4ab6-9f8c-afef0f3090a0.jpg"},{"size":"small","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/1024x768xUP/images/story/2012/bb98c79a-b08c-4ab6-9f8c-afef0f3090a0.jpg"}],"channels":[{"name":"Penny Stocks"},{"name":"Emerging Markets"},{"name":"Markets"},{"name":"General"}],"stocks":["AAPL","AMZN","F","GM","GOOGL","INTC","NKLA","NSANY","NVDA","TSLA","WKSP","NKL"],"tags":[]},"21474477":{"id":21474477,"author":"JJ Kinahan","created":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 10:09:56 -0400","updated":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 10:09:58 -0400","title":"Pharma, Biotech Stocks Start Week With A Bang After Biogen's Alzheimer's  Approval","teaser":"If you’re reading this, then apparently you weren’t affected by a global internet outage that hit many news websites. The outage appeared to hurt stock futures overnight, but things recovered to flat in the hours right before the open. ","body":"\u003cp\u003eIf you\u0026rsquo;re reading this, then apparently you weren\u0026rsquo;t affected by a global internet outage that hit many news websites. The outage appeared to hurt stock futures overnight, but things recovered to flat in the hours right before the open.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eFlat might be the word of the day, and maybe the week, at least so far. We\u0026rsquo;re flirting with record highs but not quite reaching them. Will today be the day? Maybe, but it would help to have a few catalysts. There aren\u0026rsquo;t a lot out there, by any stretch of the imagination.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s one of those times when investors have to be super careful because when there\u0026rsquo;s nothing to trade on, stories that normally wouldn\u0026rsquo;t get a lot of play can sometimes start to seem really important. The market might move quickly up or down on stuff that usually would get overlooked, especially any geopolitical news or comments from the Fed. So stay on the lookout.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe week is back-weighted a bit, mainly because of Thursday\u0026rsquo;s consumer price index report and Friday\u0026rsquo;s Michigan sentiment data. The CPI report (more below) is the last major inflation-related data the Fed will see before its meeting next week.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eToday\u0026rsquo;s data scene is dominated by the monthly Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) for April, due at 10 a.m. ET. The previous report showed more than 8.1 million job openings, which was historically high. Some economists think government assistance might be preventing people from getting back to work, but virus fears and lack of childcare could also play into this.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003ch2\u003eClose But No Cigar Again\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s only been a month since the\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;S\u0026amp;P 500 Index\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(SPX) set its latest all-time high at around 4238, but getting back to that point feels like climbing Everest.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eOn Monday, for the second straight session, the SPX crept within points of that peak only to pull back and finish lower. The\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Dow Jones Industrial Average\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e($DJI) is also flirting with and being repelled from all-time highs. Tech stocks and small-caps had the best start to the week, lifting the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNasdaq 100\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NDX) and the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eRussell 2000 Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(RUT) on Monday.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe RUT drew support from Healthcare, which owns the biggest weighting in the index. The entire Health sector powered higher Monday after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eBiogen\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003es (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/BIIB#NASDAQ\"\u003eBIIB\u003c/a\u003e) Alzheimer\u0026rsquo;s treatment (much more below). BIIB shares jumped a massive 38% on Monday. Other companies working on treatments for the disease, notably\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eEli Lilly Co\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/LLY#NYSE\"\u003eLLY\u003c/a\u003e), appeared to benefit from the approval too. LLY gained 10%.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, the bond market barely moved Monday, at least for the closely followed 10-year yield. It\u0026rsquo;s stuck below 1.55% again this morning\u0026mdash;near where some analysts see technical support at 1.52%\u0026mdash;even as investors await a couple of large government bond auctions scheduled this week. If demand at these auctions flags, maybe that could push yields back up. For the moment, however, it feels like investors are a bit more relaxed about yields after last week\u0026rsquo;s mellow jobs report.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003ch2\u003eMay CPI Data Seen Rising Less Than Previous Month\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eIf there\u0026rsquo;s anything that could change the mellow mood around rates, it\u0026rsquo;s Thursday\u0026rsquo;s May consumer price index data (CPI). Analysts expect a headline rise of 0.4% month over month, according to research firm Briefing.com. Core CPI, which strips out energy and food, is also expected to rise 0.4%. These would normally be seen as pretty high estimates, though not compared with April figures of 0.8% and 0.9%, which were monsters on a historic basis.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eFrom a single-stock perspective, there weren\u0026rsquo;t a lot of big stories yesterday outside of BIIB, LLY, and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eApple\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AAPL#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e), whose shares rebounded late after being in the red most of the day. This went against tradition because AAPL shares historically tend to fall on the first day of the company\u0026rsquo;s annual Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC).\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe rebound could have partly been technical because AAPL keeps sagging toward its 200-day moving average (now at $124.36) and then popping back up. This pattern has been going on for nearly a month, and some analysts think it could be a sign of underlying strength. On the other hand, AAPL hasn\u0026rsquo;t been able to get much traction on any of its rebounds from that technical level. The Tech sector skidded just a bit on Monday after a strong finish last week. This came as the semiconductor chip sector lost a bit of momentum.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eRecent\u0026nbsp;volatility\u0026nbsp;readings don\u0026rsquo;t show much sign of turbulence anytime soon. The\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eCboe Volatility Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(VIX) finished at seven-week lows last week and is now below 16.5. The historic average is close to 20. The VIX has been trading in five-point ranges, and it seems to be settling into the 15-20 range now after hanging out between 20-25 for a while earlier this year.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s no lack of volatility in the so-called \u0026ldquo;meme\u0026rdquo; arena, however. Both\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eGameStop\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/GME#NYSE\"\u003eGME\u003c/a\u003e) and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eAMC Entertainment\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AMC#NYSE\"\u003eAMC\u003c/a\u003e) kept up their wild ways to start the new week, each of them rising sharply. GME reports after the close tomorrow, so that could be an event for a lot of people.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eGains in the memes yesterday weren\u0026rsquo;t as massive as some of the gains (and losses) seen last week, though. By the way, if you are trying to stay away from these stocks, be sure to check any mutual funds you own, because both AMC and GME have gained a lot of market weight this year. Some of the small-cap funds, in particular, might have more exposure to these two.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003ch2\u003eSome Retail Investors Try To Ease Risk\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe Investor Movement Index\u0026reg; (IMXSM) increased 0.18 to 8.32 in May, up from its April score of 8.14. The IMX is TD\u0026nbsp;Ameritrade\u0026rsquo;s proprietary, behavior-based index, aggregating Main Street investor positions and activity to measure what investors actually were doing and how they were positioned in the markets.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eClients tracked by IMX seemed to be trying to take some risk off the table in May, for instance favoring fixed income over equities. It\u0026rsquo;s the first time since October of last year that clients have been net sellers of equities, while mostly maintaining their level of overall exposure to the markets in an environment in which the Indices were mostly unchanged.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThis is often caused by the equity buys being in higher Beta stocks. Looking forward it seems economic optimism may be on the rise\u0026mdash;the economy is slowly but surely gaining strength and the market seems to have shaken off some of the recent inflation worries for now.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eBig net-buys among the clients trackers in May included\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eAdvanced Micro Devices\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AMD#NASDAQ\"\u003eAMD\u003c/a\u003e),\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eApple\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AAPL#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e), and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eAirBnB\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/ABNB#NASDAQ\"\u003eABNB\u003c/a\u003e), the IMX found. Big net-sells included\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eModerna\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/MRNA#NASDAQ\"\u003eMRNA\u003c/a\u003e),\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNokia\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/NOK#NYSE\"\u003eNOK\u003c/a\u003e), and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003ePfizer\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/PFE#NYSE\"\u003ePFE\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/lg/2021-06-08-chart.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"philadelphia semiconductor index\" src=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/md/2021-06-08-chart.png\" style=\"height:331px; width:640px\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eCHART OF THE DAY:\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;BIOTECH REBOUNDS.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eThe\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Nasdaq Biotech Index\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NBI\u0026mdash;candlestick) has lagged the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNasdaq 100\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NDX\u0026mdash;purple line) and the broader market much of the year, but appeared to get a nice boost Monday after the FDA approved\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eBiogen\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(BIIB) Alzheimer\u0026rsquo;s disease drug. Data Source: Nasdaq.\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eChart source: The\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.tdameritrade.com/tools-and-platforms/thinkorswim.page\"\u003ethinkorswim\u0026reg; platform\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eFor illustrative purposes only. Past performance does not guarantee future results.\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTracking Prices As CPI Looms:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;With Friday\u0026rsquo;s jobs report over and done, the biggest data point ahead of next week\u0026rsquo;s Fed meeting is Thursday\u0026rsquo;s consumer price index (CPI) for May. Back in April, CPI jumped 0.8% from the month before, and core CPI (which strips out energy and food prices) rose 0.9%, the highest month-over-month rise since April 1982.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eOne question is whether recent wage growth could translate into higher prices. There\u0026rsquo;s no definitive answer, but the Chicago Tribune reported last week that some restaurant workers aren\u0026rsquo;t planning to come back to work until their benefits run out, and that restaurants in the city are having trouble filling positions. This kind of thing is something that could play into ideas that employers might have to raise wages to lure people back to jobs, which conceivably could fire up inflation. \u0026ldquo;The data for the last two months suggests that the rising demand for the labor associated with the recovery from the pandemic may have put upward pressure on wages,\u0026rdquo; the Labor Department said in the jobs report press release.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, core inflation rose 3% year-over-year in April compared with 1.6% in March, the kind of move that might seem scary if you didn\u0026rsquo;t keep it in context. Remember that the previous April was the heart of the pandemic shutdown, and May was also pretty slow last year. This means comparisons are slightly out of whack and the year-over-year number might get a little less attention from here on, at least while the economy laps those weird early days of Covid a year ago.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBig FDA Approval May Have Wider Ripples:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Yesterday\u0026rsquo;s U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval of\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Biogen\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/BIIB#NASDAQ\"\u003eBIIB\u003c/a\u003e) Aducanumab (brand name Aduhelm) wasn\u0026rsquo;t just the first time the FDA has approved a new drug for Alzheimer\u0026rsquo;s disease since 2003. It also might imply some ripples for the entire U.S. pharmaceutical industry.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eTwo of the FDA\u0026rsquo;s key thresholds for drug approval are safety and efficacy. Meaning data from clinical trials must show not just that a drug is safe to use, but also that it really works. That\u0026rsquo;s a stricter standard than the European Medicines Agency (EMA), which gives the green light \u0026ldquo;if the benefits of the medicine are greater than its risks,\u0026rdquo; as the EMA says on its internet site. Going into the Aduhelm decision, there was mixed data on the drug\u0026rsquo;s efficacy, with two studies in direct conflict. An FDA panel of outside experts actually advised the FDA to reject the drug based on questions over efficacy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eIn its approval, the FDA said Aduhelm \u0026ldquo;consistently and very convincingly reduced the level of amyloid plaques in the brain\u0026rdquo; in both studies. A reduction in those plaques is \u0026ldquo;reasonably likely to predict important benefits to patients,\u0026rdquo; the agency added. Let\u0026rsquo;s play that tape again: \u0026ldquo;Reasonably likely to predict\u0026rdquo; isn\u0026rsquo;t the same as \u0026ldquo;effective,\u0026rdquo; so maybe the FDA is taking a slightly different approach here\u0026mdash;with the caveat that the FDA will require BIIB to conduct post-approval studies to show clinical benefit and could pull approval if those fail. The other change from normal protocol was the FDA overruling its advisory committee, which is rare. All this could get people thinking about what it means for future drug approvals.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBiotech Gets A Booster\u003c/strong\u003e: The\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNasdaq Biotech Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NBI) enjoyed a nice jolt from yesterday\u0026rsquo;s BIIB drug approval, quickly jumping to 3.6% gains. Strength in BIIB, one of the sector\u0026rsquo;s largest stocks, likely played a role. But you can\u0026rsquo;t rule out some strength coming from ideas that the FDA might be more likely to approve future drugs with a slightly different approach that seems at first glance a bit more favorable for drug companies. After all, as noted above, the BIIB approval came despite conflicting trial results and an FDA panel rejection. We\u0026rsquo;ll share more thoughts tomorrow on how this might affect the biotech sector over the long-term.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eTD Ameritrade\u0026reg; commentary for educational purposes only. Member SIPC.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eImage Sourced from Pixabay\u003c/p\u003e\r\n ","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/markets/binary-options/21/06/21474477/pharma-biotech-stocks-start-week-with-a-bang-after-biogens-alzheimers-approval","image":[{"size":"large","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/2048x1536xUP/images/story/2012/laboratory-5722327_1920_1.jpg"},{"size":"thumb","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/250x187xUP/images/story/2012/laboratory-5722327_1920_1.jpg"},{"size":"small","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/1024x768xUP/images/story/2012/laboratory-5722327_1920_1.jpg"}],"channels":[{"name":"Binary Options"},{"name":"Biotech"},{"name":"Earnings"},{"name":"Government"},{"name":"News"},{"name":"Regulations"},{"name":"Retail Sales"},{"name":"FDA"},{"name":"Global"},{"name":"Markets"},{"name":"Tech"},{"name":"General"}],"stocks":["AAPL","ABNB","AMC","AMD","BIIB","GME","LLY","MRNA","NOK","PFE"],"tags":[{"name":"Biogen"},{"name":"JJ Kinahan"},{"name":"pharma"},{"name":"TD Ameritrade"}]},"21475279":{"id":21475279,"author":"Priya Nigam","created":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 13:26:57 -0400","updated":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 13:28:23 -0400","title":"What Analysts Think Of Apple WWDC's First Day, Including iOS 15 And Privacy","teaser":"Apple Inc (NASDAQ: AAPL) commenced its Worldwide Developers Conference, also known as WWDC21, on Monday, presenting online for the second straight year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Analysts, of course, paid attention.","body":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eApple Inc\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AAPL#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e) commenced its Worldwide Developers Conference, also known as WWDC21, on Monday,\u0026nbsp;presenting online for the second straight year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Analysts, of course, paid attention.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;iOS 15 was introduced and is very focused around new device privacy protections, various notifications/lock screen changes, and a revamped iMessage feature set,\u0026rdquo; Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives said in a note.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe analyst, who has an Outperform rating and a price target of $185 for the company, noted that by doubling down on privacy features, Apple has positioned itself directly on \u0026ldquo;a collision course\u0026rdquo; with \u003cstrong\u003eFacebook, Inc\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/FB#NASDAQ\"\u003eFB\u003c/a\u003e) around how users can block data tracking.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThere was other news, as well.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Today, Apple unveiled macOS Monterey, the latest version of its desktop operating system that comes with new ways for users to connect and work more fluidly across their Apple devices,\u0026rdquo; Ives further wrote.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eApple\u0026rsquo;s updates during the event were broadly in line with expectations and mostly incremental in nature, Credit Suisse\u0026#39;s Matthew Cabral and Dan Knauff said in a separate note.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe company \u0026ldquo;looks to embed AI/ML-driven curation and customization locally,\u0026rdquo; the Credit Suisse analysts noted while adding, \u0026ldquo;We view privacy and Apple\u0026rsquo;s ability to use on-device intelligence for curation/customization as potential advantages in the post-IDFA digital ad world, but recognize meaningful monetization likely takes time to ramp.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eCabral and Knauff maintained a Neutral rating for Apple, with a price target of $150.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAPPL Price Action:\u003c/strong\u003e Shares of Apple are up 0.59% at $126.65 Tuesday at publication.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Photo: macOS Monterey via Apple)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/21/06/21475279/what-analysts-think-of-apples-wwdc21-so-far-including-ios-15-and-privacy","image":[{"size":"thumb","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/250x187xUP/images/story/2012/apple.macosmonterey.png"},{"size":"small","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/1024x768xUP/images/story/2012/apple.macosmonterey.png"},{"size":"large","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/2048x1536xUP/images/story/2012/apple.macosmonterey.png"}],"channels":[{"name":"Analyst Color"},{"name":"Reiteration"},{"name":"Analyst Ratings"}],"stocks":["AAPL","FB"],"tags":[{"name":"Credit Suisse"},{"name":"Dan Knauff"},{"name":"Daniel Ives"},{"name":"Matthew Cabra"},{"name":"Wedbush"},{"name":"WWDC"},{"name":"WWDC21"}]},"21478010":{"id":21478010,"author":"Benzinga Insights","created":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 12:39:28 -0400","updated":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 12:39:29 -0400","title":"9 Information Technology Stocks Showing Unusual Options Activity In Today's Session","teaser":"This unusual options alert can help traders track potentially big trading opportunities. One must act on the contract by this date if one wants to use it.\u003cbr /\u003e\r\n - \u003cstrong\u003ePremium/Option Price:\u003c/strong\u003e The price of the contract.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eFor more information, visit our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://pro.benzinga.com/blog/how-to-understand-option-alerts/\"\u003eGuide to Understanding Options Alerts\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e or read \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/markets/options\"\u003emore about unusual options activity\u003c/a\u003e.  \u003c/p\u003e","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/markets/options/21/06/21478010/9-information-technology-stocks-showing-unusual-options-activity-in-todays-session","image":[],"channels":[{"name":"Options"}],"stocks":["AAPL","AMAT","MU","MVIS","QCOM","RIOT","SQ","VLDR","ZM"],"tags":[{"name":"BZI-AUOA"}]},"21480549":{"id":21480549,"author":"Chris Katje","created":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 16:38:57 -0400","updated":"Tue, 08 Jun 2021 16:40:49 -0400","title":"Amazon Sidewalk: What Investors, Device Owners Should Know","teaser":"One of the largest companies in the world is launching a new service that will connect networks to different internet connections via their smart devices. The new technology has some positives mentioned by the company but also comes with red flags.","body":"\u003cp\u003eOne of the largest companies in the world is launching a new service that will connect networks to different internet connections via their smart devices. The new technology has some positives mentioned by the company but also comes\u0026nbsp;with red flags.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat Happened: \u003c/strong\u003eSidewalk, an internet sharing network from \u003cstrong\u003eAmazon.com Inc \u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AMZN#NASDAQ\"\u003eAMZN\u003c/a\u003e), is an effort from the company to connect its devices and third parties.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon\u0026rsquo;s internet sharing network will connect millions of Amazon Echo and Tile devices, according to \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/22516285/amazon-sidewalk-echo-tile-ring\"\u003eRecode\u003c/a\u003e. The devices will \u0026ldquo;mesh\u0026rdquo; together using Bluetooth and radio frequencies.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eMost Amazon Echo devices and Ring cameras began sharing internet capabilities and connected to the Amazon Sidewalk network as of June 8. Some newer tracking devices will be turned on beginning June 14.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe devices will connect to other Sidewalk-enabled devices within range, like other houses in your neighborhood. This practice will allow devices to stay connected to the internet even if out of range of a Wi-Fi network or the internet goes down.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon is actively soliciting developers to add Sidewalk capabilities to other devices.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRelated Link: \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/news/21/05/21322066/eu-privacy-watchdog-initiates-probe-against-amazon-microsofts-cloud-service-to-eu-institutions-reute\"\u003eEU Privacy Watchdog Initiates Probe Against Amazon\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAmazon Sidewalk Positives, Negatives: \u003c/strong\u003eAmazon mentions several benefits for its new Sidewalk network. Having the service can allow a Ring security camera to continue to send alerts if the internet goes down. Sidewalk could also help find a lost pet.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eCareband, a wearable locator for people with dementia, is working to see if Amazon Sidewalk could help the company.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eThe biggest negatives are data and privacy. The Amazon Sidewalk network will see data passing through your neighbor\u0026rsquo;s devices and vice versa.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eOwners of Amazon Sidewalk-connected devices will also share a small amount of internet bandwidth (500mb monthly max).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eAnother potential red flag is Amazon\u0026rsquo;s decision to automatically opt in users into the Sidewalk service rather than allowing users the ability to decide if they want to be a part of the free service.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;If this service is not providing you additional functionality you need, it certainly seems like this should be off,\u0026rdquo; Northeastern University associate professor David Choffnes told Recode.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon told Recode that the decision to make the service opt out was done to make it easier for customers to take advantage of the benefits of Amazon Sidewalk.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;If you can\u0026rsquo;t provide a compelling reason for everybody to opt in, that\u0026rsquo;s a red flag,\u0026rdquo; Choffnes said.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eApple Inc\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AAPL#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e) has a similar Find My Network option that uses all Apple devices that have the service enabled. The service will also help boost the profile for Apple AirTags.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOpting Out:\u003c/strong\u003e Amazon product owners who want to opt out of the Amazon Sidewalk service have several options.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon Echo device owners can open the Alexa app, go to settings, account setting, Amazon Sidewalk and choose disabled.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eRing owners can go to control center, Amazon Sidewalk, select disabled and confirm.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003ePhoto courtesy of Amazon.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/news/21/06/21480549/amazon-sidewalk-what-investors-device-owners-should-know","image":[{"size":"large","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/2048x1536xUP/images/story/2012/echo_dot_charcoal_side_1.png"},{"size":"thumb","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/250x187xUP/images/story/2012/echo_dot_charcoal_side_1.png"},{"size":"small","url":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/1024x768xUP/images/story/2012/echo_dot_charcoal_side_1.png"}],"channels":[{"name":"News"},{"name":"Tech"},{"name":"Media"}],"stocks":["AAPL","AMZN"],"tags":[{"name":"AirTags"},{"name":"Amazon First, I\u0026rsquo;ll explain why you should buy \u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTesla\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/tsla-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTSLA\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) stock. After, I\u0026rsquo;ll take an even deeper dive into one of the EV companies you really should consider selling now\u003c/span\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEV Stocks to Buy: TSLA Stock\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTesla is a lot like Apple. It\u0026rsquo;s not a car\u0026hellip; it\u0026rsquo;s a platform.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs a $\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e580 \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ebillion company, Tesla\u0026rsquo;s valuation now eclipses \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eWalmart\u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/wmt-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWMT\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eYet, the EV leader shipped only 500,000 electric vehicles (EVs) last year, followed by \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eVolkswagen\u003c/b\u003e \u003cspan\u003e(OTCMKTS:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/vwagy-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVWAGY\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e at 212,000. The EV market is in its\u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan\u003e infancy.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e \u003cspan\u003eBut Tesla should dominate this space for a decade or more. There\u0026rsquo;s one key reason why this is true: it\u0026rsquo;s not just a car, it\u0026rsquo;s a platform. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFrom its inception, Tesla has always been a Big Tech company. Elon Musk built Tesla based around a vision of the car as an ecosystem, much like \u003cstrong\u003eApple \u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/aapl-stock-quote/\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u0026nbsp;built its insanely popular tech products. The result: Tesla has beautiful cars. Other EV makers may \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003eeventually\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan\u003e deliver beautiful cars too. But no other EV maker has a combination of both the physical network (charging stations) \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003eand\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the software. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNow, Tesla is layering on services: autonomous driving, gaming and more. By owning an end-to-end network, Tesla has control over the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003evehicle data that will enable self-driving cars and the transition to vehicle-as-a-service instead of vehicle-as-a-product.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/03/7-manufacturing-stocks-that-will-help-you-build-a-better-portfolio/\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\t7 Manufacturing Stocks That Will Help You Build a Better Portfolio\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eKnowledge is power. And that\u0026rsquo;s a great reason to bet on TSLA over other EV stocks now.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c!--nextpage--\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s entering the only safe haven for traditional automakers\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFor the most part, Tesla isn\u0026rsquo;t competing with other EV makers. It\u0026rsquo;s competing with \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003etraditional automakers in a $5 trillion global auto market. Using history as a guide, the threat is real. Since Tesla\u0026rsquo;s 2017 entry into the EV sedan with the Model S, every traditional automaker has either abandoned the sedan market \u0026mdash; e.g., \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eFord\u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/f-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eF\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eGeneral Motors\u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/gm-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGM\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) \u0026mdash; or de-emphasized it. Instead, they\u0026rsquo;ve focused on the crossover, SUV, and pickup truck markets.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNow, Tesla is moving into the traditional automaker\u0026rsquo;s safe place. The \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://electrek.co/2021/05/28/tesla-cybertruck-ui-patent-accessories-features-610-miles-range/\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCybertruck\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e is expected to launch sometime in 2022. As Tesla moves into those markets over the next two years, the traditional automakers will get hit hardest. Over the last year, Audi, Jaguar and Porsche have \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/business/future-electric-cars-2020.html\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eadded new EV models\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e intended to cut into Tesla\u0026rsquo;s electric dominance. But they have barely made a dent, at least in the United States. Sales of the Jaguar I-Pace, an electric sport utility vehicle similar to the Tesla Model Y, have totaled just over 1,000 this year. Porsche has reported similar sales for its electric sedan, the Taycan.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBottom Line on Tesla\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHowever, at 65x EBITDA, TSLA stock isn\u0026rsquo;t cheap. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut as the bellwether of the EV space, with a potential 15% CAGR over the next 5 years, investors should expect the stock to continue to trade at a premium. With \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ethe global chip squeeze likely to continue to overhang valuations\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003elook to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/05/tesla-tsla-stock-is-getting-shorted-again-nows-the-time-to-buy/\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ebuy the stock on weakness\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEV Stocks to Sell: CHPT Stock\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCHPT has the largest network of charging stations, but that\u0026rsquo;s not enough.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eChargePoint \u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/chpt-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCHPT\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) operates the largest network of independently owned EV charging stations in the world, consisting of 114,000 charging stations in 14 countries. The company was formed in a \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://mercomindia.com/chargepoint-completes-spac-deal/\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSPAC merger with Switchback Energy Acquisition\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in March. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCHPT makes money by selling charging stations, mostly to commercial customers and servicing those stations. Its r\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eevenue mix is a combination of 1) SaaS (software-as-a-service) subscriptions to its charging\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e network (34% of sales); and 2) the physical charging stations themselves (66% of Q1 sales).\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eCHPT has a low-margin business, even \u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003ci\u003ebefore\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e competition kicks in. \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDespite a capital-light business model (commercial customers pay the majority of the costs to install the company\u0026rsquo;s EV charging stations), and an almost 100% attach rate for software subscriptions, margins on CHPT\u0026rsquo;s \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u0026nbsp;subscription-based software are only 50%. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs a comparison, most subscription-based business models deliver gross margins in the 80%+ range. At the same time, margins on the company\u0026rsquo;s hardware are almost non-existent (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e5% in F2020). Combining the two segments\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, the business as a whole generates a very low \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eblended g\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eross margin of \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e23%. Management hopes to grow its subscription business as a percentage of total sales, which should help drive operating leverage and gross margin expansion. That said, the company\u0026rsquo;s gross margin forecast of 40% in 2024 (a doubling from current levels) looks aggressive.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eThere are also plenty of new entrants to consider. \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe charging station network sector is already crowded, with competition from other pure-plays like \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eBlink Charging \u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/blnk-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBLNK\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e), competition from carmakers and competition from energy giants like \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eBP\u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/bp-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBP\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eShell\u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/rds.a-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRDS.A\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e, NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/rds.b-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRDS.B\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. There are also several new SPACs about to hit the public markets:\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eVolta Charging\u003cspan\u003e with \u003cstrong\u003eTortoise Acquisition II\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/snpr-stock-quote/\"\u003eSNPR\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEVgo\u003cspan\u003e with \u003cstrong\u003eClimate Change Crisis Real Impact I Acquisition\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/clii-stock-quote/\"\u003eCLII\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEVBox \u003cspan\u003ewith \u003cstrong\u003eTPG Pace Beneficial Finance\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/tpgy-stock-quote/\"\u003eTPGY\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eChargePoint has an aggressive growth forecast, but a challenge looms.\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn F2021, ChargePoint generated revenue of $144.5 million. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eF2022 guidance calls for revenue of $195-$205 million (+38% YoY). The company\u0026rsquo;s long-term forecast looks very aggressive, calling for \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e60% compound annual growth for the next seven years, which implies $2 billion in revenue by 2027.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHowever, there\u0026rsquo;s an issue with CHPT\u0026rsquo;s growth projections (and it\u0026rsquo;s part of what makes it a less appealing play among EV stocks). Despite it having the largest charging station infrastructure today, CHPT\u0026rsquo;s charging stations are designed to handle a 240-volt charge. These can take eight hours or more to charge. While that\u0026rsquo;s fine for short-distances, the big issue for EV charging is \u0026ldquo;range anxiety,\u0026rdquo; the ability to support long-distance travel. For long distances, EV charging stations require at least 480 volts, which allows for a fast charge in under an hour. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn the other hand, \u003c/span\u003eTesla, \u003cspan\u003ewhich operates the second largest charging network, supplies 480-volt power. Tesla operates roughly 25,000 fast charging stations. In contrast CHPT only has about 1,500 fast charging units today.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c!--nextpage--\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eTesla has already outmaneuvered the market with a platform advantage. \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCHPT\u0026rsquo;s lagging 480-volt numbers are only part of the problem. Tesla figured out the range anxiety issue long ago. Despite having only sold a few thousand cars in its early years, it built out a massive charging network to address this issue immediately. Today, anyone who buys a Tesla doesn\u0026rsquo;t need to worry much about charging. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThey can drive their Tesla\u0026rsquo;s for long distances in full confidence that they will find convenient locations to recharge.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBy building a proprietary platform, Tesla locked-in two sides of the market: the installed base of cars \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003eand\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the network of charging stations. Because Tesla owns the charging network, it can choose how to price (whether to make charging free and monetize only the car), the number of stations, rollout timing and location. Tesla can also optimize its charging network for where its buyers are located and where they drive. Furthermore, the company\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u0026nbsp;is also investing in its own proprietary battery technology to deliver superior charging. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTheoretically, a Tesla vehicle can achieve a max charge rate of 250kW at a V3 supercharger, or up to 200 miles in 15 minutes.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn contrast, both traditional automakers \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003eand\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan\u003e new EV startups focused their investments on trying to build better electric cars. With the exception of newcomer Rivian (who hasn\u0026rsquo;t shipped an EV yet), the rest of the market is partnering for its charging stations. \u003c/span\u003eGeneral Motors\u003cspan\u003e is partnering with EVgo; Ford is working with Greenlots and Electrify America, and Stellantis NV is also partnering with Electrify America. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cb\u003eLucid Motors \u003c/b\u003e\u003cspan\u003e(NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/cciv-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCCIV\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) (which also hasn\u0026rsquo;t shipped an EV yet) will use Volkswagen\u0026rsquo;s Electrify America network. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThat means anyone looking to purchase an EV alternative to Tesla has to consider the car \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan\u003eand\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the charging network. As a result, there\u0026rsquo;s no EV supplier who comes close to Tesla in volume and cost.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cb\u003eBottom Line on ChargePoint\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCHPT stock trades at a rich 40 times forward sales for a low margin business facing intensifying competition, aggressive growth forecasts and ultimately a limited addressable market. All of these factors make it one of the less appealing EV stocks to consider today.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eYour comments and feedback are always welcome. Let\u0026rsquo;s continue the discussion. Email me at\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"mailto:jmakris@investorplace.com\"\u003ejmakris@investorplace.com\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eOn the date of publication, Joanna Makris did not have (either directly or indirectly) any positions in the securities mentioned in this article. \u003cem\u003eThe opinions expressed in this article are those of the writer, subject to the InvestorPlace.com \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/corporate/investorplace-publishing-guidelines/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ePublishing Guidelines\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eJoanna Makris is a Market Analyst at\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://investorplace.com/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvestorPlace.com\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. A strategic thinker and fundamental public equity investor, Joanna leverages over 20 years of experience on Wall Street covering various segments of the Technology, Media, and Telecom sectors at several global investment banks, including Mizuho Securities and Canaccord Genuity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMore From InvestorPlace\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/02/silicon-valley-whiz-kid-reveals-top-tech-stock/?cid=MKT516215\u0026amp;eid=MKT524303\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\tStock Prodigy Who Found NIO at $2\u0026hellip; Says Buy THIS Now\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/01/one-percenter-issues-urgent-warning/?cid=MKT499868\u0026amp;eid=MKT513141\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\tIt doesn\u0026rsquo;t matter if you have $500 in savings or $5 million. Do this now.\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2020/02/americas-1-stock-picker-reveals-next-1000-winner-totally-free-of-charge/?cid=MKT462609\u0026amp;eid=MKT465996\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\tTop Stock Picker Reveals His Next Potential 500% Winner\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe post \u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/06/ev-stocks-what-you-should-buy-and-what-you-should-sell-chpt-tsla-stock/\"\u003eEV Stocks: What You Should Buy and What You Should Sell\u003c/a\u003e appeared first on \u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com\"\u003eInvestorPlace\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e","url":"https://investorplace.com/2021/06/ev-stocks-what-you-should-buy-and-what-you-should-sell-chpt-tsla-stock/?utm_source=benzinga\u0026utm_medium=quotes\u0026cc=quotes\u0026cp=benzinga","image":[],"channels":[],"stocks":["AAPL","BLNK","BP","CCIV","CHPT","F","GM","RDS.A","RDS.B","TSLA","VWAGY","WMT"],"tags":[]},"21459313":{"id":21459313,"author":"InvestorPlace","created":"Mon, 07 Jun 2021 15:40:35 -0400","updated":"Mon, 07 Jun 2021 15:46:38 -0400","title":"Surprise! Netflix and Gaming Aren't a Match Made In Heaven.","teaser":"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News, Stock Advice \u0026amp; Trading Tips\nWe all know of Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) as a go-to streaming service for TV shows and movies. But what if I told you that the company is looking to venture","body":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com\"\u003eInvestorPlace - Stock Market News, Stock Advice \u0026amp; Trading Tips\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe all know of \u003cstrong\u003eNetflix\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/nflx-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNFLX\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) as a go-to streaming service for TV shows and movies. But what if I told you that the company is looking to venture into video games? At first glance, it sounds like great news for NFLX stock owners. But things aren\u0026rsquo;t that simple \u0026mdash; and the company\u0026rsquo;s success here is far from guaranteed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\t\t\u003cimg src=\"https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-8-300x169.jpg\" alt=\"Netflix (NFLX) logo displayed on a phone which has a keyboard and red background behind it\" width=\"300\" height=\"169\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003eSource: Pe3k / Shutterstock.com\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpecifically, news recently broke that Netflix is looking to hire an \u003ca href=\"https://gadgets.ndtv.com/games/news/netflix-online-video-gaming-entry-executive-hiring-expansion-apple-arcade-app-subscription-model-report-2447422\"\u003eexperienced executive in the video-game industry\u003c/a\u003e to help aid its transition. Netflix stock popped about 1% the day after the headlines started to swirl.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrently, there\u0026rsquo;s speculation that the company will offer a bundle of games similar to that of \u003cstrong\u003eApple\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/aapl-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAAPL\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) Arcade service, although the exact details of its plan are still unknown. So far, analysts are \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-netflix-will-likely-fail-at-video-games-2021-5\"\u003eskeptical about the viability of this move\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow with things cooling down for NFLX stock, let\u0026rsquo;s consider if the skeptics are right.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c!--nextpage--\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNFLX Stock: Netflix Seeks a New Audience\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past few years, Netflix has seen great success. It\u0026rsquo;s arguably the leader of the cord-cutting movement, which has led to the gradual demise of cable television. With that success, Netflix has also seen many \u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2017/11/netflix-inc-wont-go-down-without-a-fight/\"\u003estrong competitors enter the fray\u003c/a\u003e. Now \u003cstrong\u003eAmazon\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/amzn-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAMZN\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and \u003cstrong\u003eDisney\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/dis-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDIS\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) are two of its greatest challengers in the video-streaming space.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/06/7-best-manufacturing-stocks-to-buy-on-record-high-growth-data/\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\t7 Best Manufacturing Stocks to Buy on Record-High Growth Data\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite this, though, NFLX has largely remained at the top. That\u0026rsquo;s because, prior to the rise in competition, it focused much of its efforts on developing strong exclusive content. First, hit TV shows like \u003cem\u003eStranger Things\u003c/em\u003e earned respect from users. Then the company started to produce \u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2019/01/new-netflix-releases/\"\u003ehigh-quality hit films\u003c/a\u003e like \u003cem\u003eBird Box\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Netflix brand now represents quality programing \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e film. It has plenty of hits under its belt, along with critical acclaim (though it still certainly has plenty of bad stuff, too). But, while the company has succeeded in gaining recognition for quality content, its competitors are now seeing similar success with their own exclusives. For example, Disney\u0026rsquo;s widely successful show, \u003cem\u003eThe Mandalorian,\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;has \u003ca href=\"https://www.investors.com/news/disney-stock-falls-mandalorian-season-two-seen-giving-disney-plus-major-acceleration/\"\u003epowered Disney+\u003c/a\u003e and, by extension, DIS stock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a consequence, the growth narrative for NFLX stock has started to lose its luster, with video-streaming becoming an increasingly crowded world to do business. Plus, its growth factor is stretching to its limits, thanks to the pandemic. (Netflix experienced accelerated growth during this period, but it\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/health-business-coronavirus-arts-and-entertainment-e8d3f7bcc7f11f4ff726a016e97cb5af\"\u003etapering off\u003c/a\u003e.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll of that is largely what\u0026rsquo;s bringing Netflix to video games. You should expect Netflix to continue developing quality shows and films, but the possible shift to gaming indicates thirst for an even wider audience: gamers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe question is, how viable is that opportunity? And is it enough to create a turnaround story for NFLX stock?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAccessing the Gaming Opportunity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf for whatever reason you doubt the opportunity here, consider that, post-pandemic, \u0026ldquo;videogames are a \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/videogames-are-a-bigger-industry-than-sports-and-movies-combined-thanks-to-the-pandemic-11608654990\"\u003ebigger industry\u003c/a\u003e than movies and North American sports combined.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere\u0026rsquo;s a quick look at some other important video-game industry details:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs of 2020, there\u0026rsquo;s an \u003ca href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/293304/number-video-gamers/#:~:text=In%20total%2C%20there%20were%20an,across%20the%20globe%20in%202020.\"\u003eestimated \u003cem\u003e2.8 billion gamers\u003c/em\u003e in the world\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe number of gamers might diminish as we return to normal, but chances are many will retain the hobby, especially with the release of new gaming consoles from \u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/msft-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMSFT\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and \u003cstrong\u003eSony\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/sony-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSONY\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMobile gaming comprises \u003ca href=\"https://venturebeat.com/2021/01/06/superdata-games-grew-12-to-139-9-billion-in-2020-amid-pandemic/\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;58% of the total games market.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe gaming industry has been growing exponentially over the past decade. Although its growth might not accelerate again like it did during the pandemic, it\u0026rsquo;s definitely a good spot to be in. There\u0026rsquo;s clearly a massive audience to tap into here.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut how does Netflix and NFLX stock fit into this space? With all of these exciting factors to support the move, it seems like a no-brainer, right?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c!--nextpage--\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNetflix\u0026rsquo;s Inevitable Role Reversal\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe opportunity here for NFLX stock isn\u0026rsquo;t so straightforward. While the company holds name-brand recognition in the entertainment industry more broadly, the gaming niche is an entirely different animal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2021/06/7-best-vaccine-stocks-for-their-pipeline-potential/\"\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\t7 Best Vaccine Stocks for Their Pipeline Potential\t\t\t\t\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis situation is the inverse of what made Netflix successful with video streaming. Its would-be competitors in gaming are the \u003cem\u003elong-reigning\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003echampions\u003c/em\u003e of the space, fortified by decades worth of quality video-game franchises and products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMuch like Netflix is a champion in streaming content, companies like Sony, Microsoft and \u003cstrong\u003eNintendo\u003c/strong\u003e (OTCMKTS:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/ntdoy-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNTDOY\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) have led the general direction of the gaming industry since the mid-1990s. There are also plenty of PC-gaming-focused leaders in the mix, too. For example, \u003cstrong\u003eValve Software\u003c/strong\u003e owns the Steam gaming platform, which is ubiquitous among PC gamers. And don\u0026rsquo;t forget mega gaming studios like \u003cstrong\u003eElectronic Arts\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/ea-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEA\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and \u003cstrong\u003eActivision Blizzard\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/atvi-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eATVI\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany of these potential competitors have been working on their own streaming services or Netflix-like solutions, backed by exclusive catalogues of insanely popular games. In other words, the \u0026ldquo;Netflix of Gaming\u0026rdquo; is \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/04/microsoft-reveals-more-details-about-its-xcloud-game-streaming-service.html\"\u003enot a unique concept\u003c/a\u003e. In fact, right now it\u0026rsquo;s called Xbox Game Pass \u0026mdash; a \u003ca href=\"https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2021-02-17-is-xbox-game-pass-too-good-to-be-true\"\u003ewidely successful platform\u003c/a\u003e led by Microsoft which leverages the company\u0026rsquo;s massive library of games to help ensure success. Meanwhile, Sony \u0026mdash; MSFT\u0026rsquo;s long-time adversary \u0026mdash; is working on a \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/paultassi/2021/04/12/what-would-a-sony-counterpunch-to-xbox-game-pass-actually-look-like/\"\u003ecompetitive solution\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eContent is a \u003cem\u003ehuge\u003c/em\u003e driver for these platforms and it\u0026rsquo;s king in the world of gaming \u0026mdash; remember that as we dive deeper into the potential opportunity for NFLX stock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePut it all together and Netflix probably won\u0026rsquo;t enter the gaming industry as a legitimate disruptor. At least, not right away. Instead, it\u0026rsquo;ll likely be a follower. The company will try to leech from the triumphs of others. However, when it comes to the gaming business, history shows that this approach \u003cem\u003eusually isn\u0026rsquo;t successful.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAn Entry Into Gaming Won\u0026rsquo;t Be Easy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn an interview with \u003cem\u003eBusiness Insider\u003c/em\u003e, analyst Joost van Dreunen put it bluntly: \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-netflix-will-likely-fail-at-video-games-2021-5\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;Big tech sucks at games.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e He cites the recent failures of \u003cstrong\u003eAlphabet\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/goog-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGOOG\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e, NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/googl-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGOOGL\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e), \u003cstrong\u003eFacebook\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/fb-stock-quote/\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFB\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and Amazon to tap into the industry as prime examples.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat\u0026rsquo;s the main flaw in big tech\u0026rsquo;s approach, according to Dreunen? \u0026ldquo;They look at it in a way that distribution goes before the content [\u0026hellip;] and that\u0026rsquo;s the wrong way around.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost long-time gamers likely understand where Dreunen is coming from here, but maybe with an added nuance. The \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/02/26/racism-misogyny-death-threats-why-cant-booming-video-game-industry-curb-toxicity/\"\u003egaming community\u0026rsquo;s ferocity\u003c/a\u003e is undeniable. While not every gamer fits into the \u0026ldquo;toxic\u0026rdquo; category, the community has repeatedly demonstrated an ability to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/28/eas-day-of-reckoning-is-here-after-star-wars-game-uproar.html\"\u003epunish companies\u003c/a\u003e for \u0026ldquo;wrongdoings\u0026rdquo; like no other.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is largely why it\u0026rsquo;s hard for companies like Apple and Google to tap into the space, despite their impressive pedigrees in tech. Regardless of how noble or silly the cause, gamers \u003ca href=\"https://investorplace.com/2020/08/antitrust-catch-apple-aapl-stock-sooner/\"\u003erally against outsiders\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese big-tech companies \u0026ldquo;dabble\u0026rdquo; in video games, but that dabbling quickly marks them as outsiders. They don\u0026rsquo;t \u0026ldquo;get it.\u0026rdquo; So, they \u003ca href=\"https://screenrant.com/google-stadia-damning-report-failing/#:~:text=In%20a%20new%20report%20from,giving%20away%20controllers%20for%20free.\"\u003eusually don\u0026rsquo;t succeed\u003c/a\u003e, regardless of how technically impressive their product might seem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs Dreunen points out, such failures usually come from a lack of attention to content. Taking it a step further, I\u0026rsquo;d argue that the \u0026ldquo;outsider\u0026rdquo; mindset usually means their content won\u0026rsquo;t resonate with gamers anyway.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUntil proven otherwise, Netflix is an outsider to the world of gaming. I think it will stay that way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c!--nextpage--\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Bottom Line on NFLX Stock\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis doesn\u0026rsquo;t mean there\u0026rsquo;s no opportunity here for NFLX stock to benefit in the long run. However, the company\u0026rsquo;s approach to content is undoubtedly the key to its success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the rumors are true, then Netflix will offer an arcade suite of games. This seems like a smart move. After all, it can leverage its brand recognition and target a casual audience with such games. As mentioned earlier, most gamers actually play on mobile devices (58%). The games on mobile are usually much less intricate \u0026mdash; and much better suited for arcade-like designs. Likewise, it\u0026rsquo;s possible that NFLX could integrate its gaming suite with its mobile app to better target this group of gamers. (Remember, many of them likely already have a subscription to Netflix).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat all said, if Netflix is gearing toward a \u003cem\u003ehardcore\u003c/em\u003e gaming audience, then it seems like a match-up similar to \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-wUdetAAlY\"\u003eBambi vs. Godzilla\u003c/a\u003e. (Hint: this isn\u0026rsquo;t a redeeming David-and-Goliath type story). To the hardcore gaming community, NFLX is an outsider bound to be crushed by long-standing titans. Really, the only advantage it has here is if it can exploit the popularity of Netflix Originals and create games based on its series and films. But any gamer will tell you, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/2003/12/why-do-video-games-based-on-movies-suck/\"\u003esuch games are usually atrocious\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, for now I\u0026rsquo;d stick to the sidelines and wait until Netflix gives a clearer outline for its plans before making any big moves based on this news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRobert Waldo is a web editor for InvestorPlace.com. On the date of publication, he did not hold any position (either directly or indirectly) in any of the securities mentioned in this article.
